<|endoftext|>/* Input to this function is a string containing multiple groups of nested parentheses. Your goal is to
  separate those group into separate strings and return the list of those.
  Separate groups are balanced (each open brace is properly closed) and not nested within each other
  Ignore any spaces in the input string.
  >>> separate_paren_groups('( ) (( )) (( )( ))')
  ['()', '(())', '(()())']
  */
const separate_paren_groups = (paren_string) => {
  const groups = [];
  let current_group = [];
  let open_brace_count = 0;

  for (let i = 0; i < paren_string.length; i++) {
    const char = paren_string[i];
    if (char === '(') {
      open_brace_count++;
      current_group.push(char);
    } else if (char === ')') {
      open_brace_count--;
      if (open_brace_count === 0) {
        groups.push(current_group);
        current_group = [];
      }
    } else {
      current_group.push(char);
    }
  }

  if (current_group.length > 0) {
    groups.push(current_group);
  }

  return groups;
};

test:
const testByLength = () => {
  console.assert(
    JSON.stringify(byLength([2, 1, 1, 4, 5, 8, 2, 3])) ===
    JSON.stringify([
      'Eight',
      'Five',
      'Four',
      'Three',
      'Two',
      'Two',
      'One',
      'One',
    ])
  )
  console.assert(JSON.stringify(byLength([])) === JSON.stringify([]))
  console.assert(
    JSON.stringify(byLength([1, -1, 55])) === JSON.stringify(['One'])
  )
  console.assert(
    JSON.stringify(byLength([1, -1, 3, 2])) ===
    JSON.stringify(['Three', 'Two', 'One'])
  )
  console.assert(
    JSON.stringify(byLength([9, 4, 8])) ===
    JSON.stringify(['Nine', 'Eight', 'Four'])
  )
}

<|endoftext|>/*Task
  We are given two strings s and c, you have to deleted all the characters in s that are equal to any character in c
  then check if the result string is palindrome.
  A string is called palindrome if it reads the same backward as forward.
  You should return a tuple containing the result string and true/false for the check.
  Example
  For s = "abcde", c = "ae", the result should be ('bcd',false)
  For s = "abcdef", c = "b"  the result should be ('acdef',false)
  For s = "abcdedcba", c = "ab", the result should be ('cdedc',true)
  */
const reverse_delete = (s, c) => {
  let result = '';
  let isPalindrome = true;
  for (let i = 0; i < s.length; i += 1) {
    if (s[i]!== c[i]) {
      result += s[i];
    } else {
      isPalindrome = false;
    }
  }
  return [result, isPalindrome];
};

  Given an array of integers nums, find the minimum sum of any non-empty sub-array
  of nums.
  Example
  min_sub_array_sum([2, 3, 4, 1, 2, 4]) == 1
  min_sub_array_sum([-1, -2, -3]) == -6
  */
const min_sub_array_sum = (nums) => {
  let min = Number.MAX_SAFE_INTEGER;
  for (let i = 0; i < nums.length; i++) {
    const curr = nums[i];
    for (let j = i + 1; j < nums.length; j++) {
      const next = nums[j];
      if (curr + next < min) {
        min = curr + next;
      }
    }
  }
  return min;
};

  console.assert(JSON.stringify(splitWords('aaaBb')) === JSON.stringify(1))

  tri(n) =  tri(n - 1) + tri(n - 2) + tri(n + 1), if n is odd.

  tri(2) = 1 + (2 / 2) = 2
  tri(4) = 3
  tri(3) = tri(2) + tri(1) + tri(4)

  */
const tri = (n) => {
  let arr = [];
  arr.push(3);
  if (n % 2 === 0) {
    for (let i = 3; i <= n; i++) {

  } else {
    for (let i = 3; i <= n; i++) {
      arr.push(tri(n - 1) + tri(n - 2) + tri(n + 1));

  }

  for (let i = 1; i <= n; i++) {

  Note: if there are several items with similar sum of their digits,

  */
const order_by_points = (nums) => {
  const map = new Map();

    const digits = num.toString().split('');
    const sumOfDigits = digits.reduce((acc, digit) => acc + parseInt(digit, 10), 0);
    map.set(sumOfDigits, num);
  }
  return Array.from(map.values()).sort((a, b) => b - a);
};

   Example:
      even_odd_count(-12) ==> (1, 1)
      even_odd_count(123) ==> (1, 2)
  */
const even_odd_count = (num) => {
  let evenCount = 0;
  let oddCount = 0;
  while (num > 0) {
    if (num % 2 === 0) {
      evenCount++;
    } else {
      oddCount++;
    }
    num = Math.floor(num / 10);
  }
  return [evenCount, oddCount];
};

  sides form a right-angled triangle, false otherwise.
  A right-angled triangle is a triangle in which one angle is right angle or
  90 degree.
  Example:
  right_angle_triangle(3, 4, 5) == true
  right_angle_triangle(1, 2, 3) == false
  */
const right_angle_triangle = (a, b, c) => {
  const ab = a - b;
  const bc = b - c;
  const ac = a - c;
  return ab * bc > ac * bc;

<|endoftext|>/*You are given a string s.
  if s[i] is a letter, reverse its case from lower to upper or vise versa, 
  otherwise keep it as it is.
  If the string contains no letters, reverse the string.
  The function should return the resulted string.
  Examples
  solve("1234") = "4321"
  solve("ab") = "AB"
  solve("#a@C") = "#A@c"
  */
const solve = (s) => {
  let result = "";
  for (let i = 0; i < s.length; i++) {
    if (s[i] >= 'a' && s[i] <= 'z') {
      result += String.fromCharCode(s[i] - 32);
    } else if (s[i] >= 'A' && s[i] <= 'Z') {
      result += String.fromCharCode(s[i] + 32);
    } else {
      result += s[i];
    }
  }
  return result;
};

  */
const string_to_sha256 = (text) => {
  if (!text) {
    return null;
  }
  const sha256sum = crypto.createHash('sha256');
  sha256sum.update(text);
  return sha256sum.digest('hex');
};

  for (let i = 1; i <= n; i++) {
    if (i % 3 === 0 || i % 5 === 0) {
      count++;
    }
  }
  return count;
};

<|endoftext|>/* Insert a number 'delimeter' between every two consecutive elements of input list `numbers'
  >>> intersperse([], 4)
  []
  >>> intersperse([1, 2, 3], 4)
  [1, 4, 2, 4, 3]
  */
const intersperse = (numbers, delimeter) => {
  const result = [];
  let i = 0;
  let j = 0;
  while (i < numbers.length) {
    while (j < numbers.length && numbers[j] === numbers[i]) {
      j++;
    }
    result.push(numbers[i]);
    if (j < numbers.length) {
      result.push(delimeter);
    }
    i++;
  }
  return result;
};

  "21"

  "12"
  */
const circular_shift = (x, shift) => {
  let digits = x.toString().split('');
  digits = digits.reverse();
  digits = digits.splice(0, shift);
  return digits.reverse().join('');

  Strange sorting, is when you start with the minimum value,
  then maximum of the remaining integers, then minimum and so on.

  Examples:
  strange_sort_list([1, 2, 3, 4]) == [1, 4, 2, 3]

    return 0;
  });
  return sorted_list;
};

const triangle_area = (a, b, c) => {

    return -1;
  }
  return Math.sqrt(a * a + b * b + c * c);

const sort_array = (array) => {
  const len = array.length;
  if (len <= 1) {
    return array;
  }
  const mid = Math.floor(len / 2);
  const left = array.slice(0, mid);
  const right = array.slice(mid);
  const leftSum = left
   .map((value) => value + value)

  const isOdd = (leftSum + rightSum) % 2 === 1;
  const result = isOdd? left.concat(right) : right.concat(left);
  return result;
};

  in the sequence.
  >>> rolling_max([1, 2, 3, 2, 3, 4, 2])
  [1, 2, 3, 3, 3, 4, 4]
  */
const rolling_max = (numbers) => {
  const result = [];
  let max;
  for (let i = 0; i < numbers.length; i++) {
    max = numbers[i];
    for (let j = i + 1; j < numbers.length; j++) {
      if (numbers[j] > max) {
        max = numbers[j];
      }
    }
    result.push(max);
  }
  return result;
};

};
